member.name: T:Amazon.Glue.Model.StartJobRunRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the StartJobRun operation. Starts a job run using a job definition.

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.StartJobRunRequest.AllocatedCapacity
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property AllocatedCapacity.
This field is deprecated. Use MaxCapacity instead.
The number of Glue data processing units (DPUs) to allocate to this JobRun. From 2 to 100 DPUs can be allocated; the default is 10. A DPU is a relative measure of processing power that consists of 4 vCPUs of compute capacity and 16 GB of memory. For more information, see the Glue pricing page.

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.StartJobRunRequest.Arguments
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Arguments.
The job arguments specifically for this run. For this job run, they replace the default arguments set in the job definition itself.
You can specify arguments here that your own job-execution script consumes, as well as arguments that Glue itself consumes.
For information about how to specify and consume your own Job arguments, see the Calling Glue APIs in Python topic in the developer guide.
For information about the key-value pairs that Glue consumes to set up your job, see the Special Parameters Used by Glue topic in the developer guide.

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.StartJobRunRequest.JobName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property JobName.
The name of the job definition to use.

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.StartJobRunRequest.JobRunId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property JobRunId.
The ID of a previous JobRun to retry.

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.StartJobRunRequest.MaxCapacity
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MaxCapacity.
The number of Glue data processing units (DPUs) that can be allocated when this job runs. A DPU is a relative measure of processing power that consists of 4 vCPUs of compute capacity and 16 GB of memory. For more information, see the Glue pricing page.
Do not set Max Capacity if using WorkerType and NumberOfWorkers.
The value that can be allocated for MaxCapacity depends on whether you are running a Python shell job, or an Apache Spark ETL job:
When you specify a Python shell job (JobCommand.Name="pythonshell"), you can allocate either 0.0625 or 1 DPU. The default is 0.0625 DPU.
When you specify an Apache Spark ETL job (JobCommand.Name="glueetl"), you can allocate from 2 to 100 DPUs. The default is 10 DPUs. This job type cannot have a fractional DPU allocation.

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.StartJobRunRequest.NotificationProperty
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NotificationProperty.
Specifies configuration properties of a job run notification.

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.StartJobRunRequest.NumberOfWorkers
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NumberOfWorkers.
The number of workers of a defined workerType that are allocated when a job runs.
The maximum number of workers you can define are 299 for G.1X, and 149 for G.2X.

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.StartJobRunRequest.SecurityConfiguration
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SecurityConfiguration.
The name of the SecurityConfiguration structure to be used with this job run.

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.StartJobRunRequest.Timeout
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Timeout.
The JobRun timeout in minutes. This is the maximum time that a job run can consume resources before it is terminated and enters TIMEOUT status. The default is 2,880 minutes (48 hours). This overrides the timeout value set in the parent job.

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.StartJobRunRequest.WorkerType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property WorkerType.
The type of predefined worker that is allocated when a job runs. Accepts a value of Standard, G.1X, or G.2X.
For the Standard worker type, each worker provides 4 vCPU, 16 GB of memory and a 50GB disk, and 2 executors per worker.
For the G.1X worker type, each worker provides 4 vCPU, 16 GB of memory and a 64GB disk, and 1 executor per worker.
For the G.2X worker type, each worker provides 8 vCPU, 32 GB of memory and a 128GB disk, and 1 executor per worker.

member.summary:
Gets and sets the property JobRunId.
The ID assigned to this job run.

member.name: T:Amazon.Glue.Model.StartMLEvaluationTaskRunRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the StartMLEvaluationTaskRun operation. Starts a task to estimate the quality of the transform.
When you provide label sets as examples of truth, Glue machine learning uses some of those examples to learn from them. The rest of the labels are used as a test to estimate quality.
Returns a unique identifier for the run. You can call GetMLTaskRun to get more information about the stats of the EvaluationTaskRun.

The unique identifier associated with this run.

member.name: T:Amazon.Glue.Model.StartMLLabelingSetGenerationTaskRunRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the StartMLLabelingSetGenerationTaskRun operation. Starts the active learning workflow for your machine learning transform to improve the transform's quality by generating label sets and adding labels.
When the StartMLLabelingSetGenerationTaskRun finishes, Glue will have generated a "labeling set" or a set of questions for humans to answer.
In the case of the FindMatches transform, these questions are of the form, “What is the correct way to group these rows together into groups composed entirely of matching records?”
After the labeling process is finished, you can upload your labels with a call to StartImportLabelsTaskRun. After StartImportLabelsTaskRun finishes, all future runs of the machine learning transform will use the new and improved labels and perform a higher-quality transformation.

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.TransformFilterCriteria.GlueVersion
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property GlueVersion.
This value determines which version of Glue this machine learning transform is compatible with. Glue 1.0 is recommended for most customers. If the value is not set, the Glue compatibility defaults to Glue 0.9. For more information, see Glue Versions in the developer guide.

member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Name.
A unique transform name that is used to filter the machine learning transforms.

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.TransformFilterCriteria.Schema
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Schema.
Filters on datasets with a specific schema. The Map<Column, Type> object is an array of key-value pairs representing the schema this transform accepts, where Column is the name of a column, and Type is the type of the data such as an integer or string. Has an upper bound of 100 columns.

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.TransformFilterCriteria.Status
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Status.
Filters the list of machine learning transforms by the last known status of the transforms (to indicate whether a transform can be used or not). One of "NOT_READY", "READY", or "DELETING".

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.TransformFilterCriteria.TransformType
member.summary:

The type of machine learning transform that is used to filter the machine learning transforms.

member.name: T:Amazon.Glue.Model.UpdateMLTransformRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the UpdateMLTransform operation. Updates an existing machine learning transform. Call this operation to tune the algorithm parameters to achieve better results.
After calling this operation, you can call the StartMLEvaluationTaskRun operation to assess how well your new parameters achieved your goals (such as improving the quality of your machine learning transform, or making it more cost-effective).

A description of the transform. The default is an empty string.

member.summary:
Gets and sets the property GlueVersion.
This value determines which version of Glue this machine learning transform is compatible with. Glue 1.0 is recommended for most customers. If the value is not set, the Glue compatibility defaults to Glue 0.9. For more information, see Glue Versions in the developer guide.

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.UpdateMLTransformRequest.MaxCapacity
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MaxCapacity.
The number of Glue data processing units (DPUs) that are allocated to task runs for this transform. You can allocate from 2 to 100 DPUs; the default is 10. A DPU is a relative measure of processing power that consists of 4 vCPUs of compute capacity and 16 GB of memory. For more information, see the Glue pricing page.
When the WorkerType field is set to a value other than Standard, the MaxCapacity field is set automatically and becomes read-only.

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.UpdateMLTransformRequest.MaxRetries
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MaxRetries.
The maximum number of times to retry a task for this transform after a task run fails.

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.UpdateMLTransformRequest.Name
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Name.
The unique name that you gave the transform when you created it.

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.UpdateMLTransformRequest.NumberOfWorkers
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NumberOfWorkers.
The number of workers of a defined workerType that are allocated when this task runs.

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.UpdateMLTransformRequest.Parameters
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Parameters.
The configuration parameters that are specific to the transform type (algorithm) used. Conditionally dependent on the transform type.

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.UpdateMLTransformRequest.Role
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Role.
The name or Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role with the required permissions.

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.UpdateMLTransformRequest.Timeout
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Timeout.
The timeout for a task run for this transform in minutes. This is the maximum time that a task run for this transform can consume resources before it is terminated and enters TIMEOUT status. The default is 2,880 minutes (48 hours).

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.UpdateMLTransformRequest.TransformId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TransformId.
A unique identifier that was generated when the transform was created.

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.UpdateMLTransformRequest.WorkerType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property WorkerType.
The type of predefined worker that is allocated when this task runs. Accepts a value of Standard, G.1X, or G.2X.
For the Standard worker type, each worker provides 4 vCPU, 16 GB of memory and a 50GB disk, and 2 executors per worker.
For the G.1X worker type, each worker provides 4 vCPU, 16 GB of memory and a 64GB disk, and 1 executor per worker.
For the G.2X worker type, each worker provides 8 vCPU, 32 GB of memory and a 128GB disk, and 1 executor per worker.

member.summary: This is the response object from the UpdateMLTransform operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.UpdateMLTransformResponse.TransformId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TransformId.
The unique identifier for the transform that was updated.

member.name: T:Amazon.Glue.Model.UpdateSchemaRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the UpdateSchema operation. Updates the description, compatibility setting, or version checkpoint for a schema set.
For updating the compatibility setting, the call will not validate compatibility for the entire set of schema versions with the new compatibility setting. If the value for Compatibility is provided, the VersionNumber (a checkpoint) is also required. The API will validate the checkpoint version number for consistency.
If the value for the VersionNumber (checkpoint) is provided, Compatibility is optional and this can be used to set/reset a checkpoint for the schema.
This update will happen only if the schema is in the AVAILABLE state.

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.UpdateSchemaRequest.Compatibility
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Compatibility.
The new compatibility setting for the schema.

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.UpdateSchemaRequest.Description
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Description.
The new description for the schema.

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.UpdateSchemaRequest.SchemaId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SchemaId.
This is a wrapper structure to contain schema identity fields. The structure contains:
SchemaId$SchemaArn: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the schema. One of SchemaArn or SchemaName has to be provided.
SchemaId$SchemaName: The name of the schema. One of SchemaArn or SchemaName has to be provided.

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.UpdateSchemaRequest.SchemaVersionNumber
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SchemaVersionNumber.
Version number required for check pointing. One of VersionNumber or Compatibility has to be provided.

member.name: T:Amazon.Glue.Model.UpdateSchemaResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the UpdateSchema operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.UpdateSchemaResponse.RegistryName

The name of the registry that contains the schema.

member.summary:

The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the schema.

member.name: P:Amazon.Glue.Model.UpdateSchemaResponse.SchemaName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SchemaName.
The name of the schema.

member.name: T:Amazon.Glue.Model.Workflow

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.AmazonGlueClient.#ctor
member.summary:
Constructs AmazonGlueClient with the credentials loaded from the application's default configuration, and if unsuccessful from the Instance Profile service on an EC2 instance.
Example App.config with credentials set.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <configuration> <appSettings> <add key="AWSProfileName" value="AWS Default"/> </appSettings> </configuration>

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.AmazonGlueClient.BatchDeleteTable(Amazon.Glue.Model.BatchDeleteTableRequest)
member.summary:
Deletes multiple tables at once.
After completing this operation, you no longer have access to the table versions and partitions that belong to the deleted table. Glue deletes these "orphaned" resources asynchronously in a timely manner, at the discretion of the service.
To ensure the immediate deletion of all related resources, before calling BatchDeleteTable, use DeleteTableVersion or BatchDeleteTableVersion, and DeletePartition or BatchDeletePartition, to delete any resources that belong to the table.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the BatchDeleteTable service method.
member.returns: The response from the BatchDeleteTable service method, as returned by Glue.
member.exception: A specified entity does not exist
An internal service error occurred.
The input provided was not valid.
The operation timed out.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for BatchDeleteTable Operation

To ensure the immediate deletion of all related resources, before calling BatchDeleteTable, use DeleteTableVersion or BatchDeleteTableVersion, and DeletePartition or BatchDeletePartition, to delete any resources that belong to the table.

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.AmazonGlueClient.CancelMLTaskRun(Amazon.Glue.Model.CancelMLTaskRunRequest)
member.summary: Cancels (stops) a task run. Machine learning task runs are asynchronous tasks that Glue runs on your behalf as part of various machine learning workflows. You can cancel a machine learning task run at any time by calling CancelMLTaskRun with a task run's parent transform's TransformID and the task run's TaskRunId.

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.AmazonGlueClient.CreateMLTransform(Amazon.Glue.Model.CreateMLTransformRequest)
member.summary:
Creates an Glue machine learning transform. This operation creates the transform and all the necessary parameters to train it.
Call this operation as the first step in the process of using a machine learning transform (such as the FindMatches transform) for deduplicating data. You can provide an optional Description, in addition to the parameters that you want to use for your algorithm.
You must also specify certain parameters for the tasks that Glue runs on your behalf as part of learning from your data and creating a high-quality machine learning transform. These parameters include Role, and optionally, AllocatedCapacity, Timeout, and MaxRetries. For more information, see Jobs.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the CreateMLTransform service method.
member.returns: The response from the CreateMLTransform service method, as returned by Glue.
member.exception: Access to a resource was denied.
A resource to be created or added already exists.
The same unique identifier was associated with two different records.
An internal service error occurred.
The input provided was not valid.
The operation timed out.
A resource numerical limit was exceeded.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for CreateMLTransform Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.AmazonGlueClient.CreateSchema(Amazon.Glue.Model.CreateSchemaRequest)
member.summary:
Creates a new schema set and registers the schema definition. Returns an error if the schema set already exists without actually registering the version.
When the schema set is created, a version checkpoint will be set to the first version. Compatibility mode "DISABLED" restricts any additional schema versions from being added after the first schema version. For all other compatibility modes, validation of compatibility settings will be applied only from the second version onwards when the RegisterSchemaVersion API is used.
When this API is called without a RegistryId, this will create an entry for a "default-registry" in the registry database tables, if it is not already present.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the CreateSchema service method.
member.returns: The response from the CreateSchema service method, as returned by Glue.
member.exception: Access to a resource was denied.
A resource to be created or added already exists.
A specified entity does not exist
An internal service error occurred.
The input provided was not valid.
A resource numerical limit was exceeded.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for CreateSchema Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.AmazonGlueClient.DeleteDatabase(Amazon.Glue.Model.DeleteDatabaseRequest)
member.summary:
Removes a specified database from a Data Catalog.
After completing this operation, you no longer have access to the tables (and all table versions and partitions that might belong to the tables) and the user-defined functions in the deleted database. Glue deletes these "orphaned" resources asynchronously in a timely manner, at the discretion of the service.
To ensure the immediate deletion of all related resources, before calling DeleteDatabase, use DeleteTableVersion or BatchDeleteTableVersion, DeletePartition or BatchDeletePartition, DeleteUserDefinedFunction, and DeleteTable or BatchDeleteTable, to delete any resources that belong to the database.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the DeleteDatabase service method.
member.returns: The response from the DeleteDatabase service method, as returned by Glue.
member.exception: Two processes are trying to modify a resource simultaneously.
A specified entity does not exist
An internal service error occurred.
The input provided was not valid.
The operation timed out.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for DeleteDatabase Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.AmazonGlueClient.DeleteMLTransform(Amazon.Glue.Model.DeleteMLTransformRequest)
member.summary: Deletes an Glue machine learning transform. Machine learning transforms are a special type of transform that use machine learning to learn the details of the transformation to be performed by learning from examples provided by humans. These transformations are then saved by Glue. If you no longer need a transform, you can delete it by calling DeleteMLTransforms. However, any Glue jobs that still reference the deleted transform will no longer succeed.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the DeleteMLTransform service method.
member.returns: The response from the DeleteMLTransform service method, as returned by Glue.
member.exception: A specified entity does not exist

The operation timed out.

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.AmazonGlueClient.DeleteSchemaVersions(Amazon.Glue.Model.DeleteSchemaVersionsRequest)
member.summary:
Remove versions from the specified schema. A version number or range may be supplied. If the compatibility mode forbids deleting of a version that is necessary, such as BACKWARDS_FULL, an error is returned. Calling the GetSchemaVersions API after this call will list the status of the deleted versions.
When the range of version numbers contain check pointed version, the API will return a 409 conflict and will not proceed with the deletion. You have to remove the checkpoint first using the DeleteSchemaCheckpoint API before using this API.
You cannot use the DeleteSchemaVersions API to delete the first schema version in the schema set. The first schema version can only be deleted by the DeleteSchema API. This operation will also delete the attached SchemaVersionMetadata under the schema versions. Hard deletes will be enforced on the database.
If the compatibility mode forbids deleting of a version that is necessary, such as BACKWARDS_FULL, an error is returned.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the DeleteSchemaVersions service method.
member.returns: The response from the DeleteSchemaVersions service method, as returned by Glue.
member.exception: Access to a resource was denied.
Two processes are trying to modify a resource simultaneously.
A specified entity does not exist
The input provided was not valid.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for DeleteSchemaVersions Operation

When the range of version numbers contain check pointed version, the API will return a 409 conflict and will not proceed with the deletion. You have to remove the checkpoint first using the DeleteSchemaCheckpoint API before using this API.
You cannot use the DeleteSchemaVersions API to delete the first schema version in the schema set. The first schema version can only be deleted by the DeleteSchema API. This operation will also delete the attached SchemaVersionMetadata under the schema versions. Hard deletes will be enforced on the database.
If the compatibility mode forbids deleting of a version that is necessary, such as BACKWARDS_FULL, an error is returned.

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.AmazonGlueClient.DeleteTable(Amazon.Glue.Model.DeleteTableRequest)
member.summary:
Removes a table definition from the Data Catalog.
After completing this operation, you no longer have access to the table versions and partitions that belong to the deleted table. Glue deletes these "orphaned" resources asynchronously in a timely manner, at the discretion of the service.
To ensure the immediate deletion of all related resources, before calling DeleteTable, use DeleteTableVersion or BatchDeleteTableVersion, and DeletePartition or BatchDeletePartition, to delete any resources that belong to the table.

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.AmazonGlueClient.GetMLTaskRuns(Amazon.Glue.Model.GetMLTaskRunsRequest)
member.summary:
Gets a list of runs for a machine learning transform. Machine learning task runs are asynchronous tasks that Glue runs on your behalf as part of various machine learning workflows. You can get a sortable, filterable list of machine learning task runs by calling GetMLTaskRuns with their parent transform's TransformID and other optional parameters as documented in this section.
This operation returns a list of historic runs and must be paginated.

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.AmazonGlueClient.GetSchemaByDefinition(Amazon.Glue.Model.GetSchemaByDefinitionRequest)
member.summary: Retrieves a schema by the SchemaDefinition. The schema definition is sent to the Schema Registry, canonicalized, and hashed. If the hash is matched within the scope of the SchemaName or ARN (or the default registry, if none is supplied), that schema’s metadata is returned. Otherwise, a 404 or NotFound error is returned. Schema versions in Deleted statuses will not be included in the results.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the GetSchemaByDefinition service method.

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.AmazonGlueClient.ListCrawlers(Amazon.Glue.Model.ListCrawlersRequest)
member.summary:
Retrieves the names of all crawler resources in this Amazon Web Services account, or the resources with the specified tag. This operation allows you to see which resources are available in your account, and their names.
This operation takes the optional Tags field, which you can use as a filter on the response so that tagged resources can be retrieved as a group. If you choose to use tags filtering, only resources with the tag are retrieved.

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.AmazonGlueClient.RegisterSchemaVersion(Amazon.Glue.Model.RegisterSchemaVersionRequest)
member.summary:
Adds a new version to the existing schema. Returns an error if new version of schema does not meet the compatibility requirements of the schema set. This API will not create a new schema set and will return a 404 error if the schema set is not already present in the Schema Registry.
If this is the first schema definition to be registered in the Schema Registry, this API will store the schema version and return immediately. Otherwise, this call has the potential to run longer than other operations due to compatibility modes. You can call the GetSchemaVersion API with the SchemaVersionId to check compatibility modes.
If the same schema definition is already stored in Schema Registry as a version, the schema ID of the existing schema is returned to the caller.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the RegisterSchemaVersion service method.
member.returns: The response from the RegisterSchemaVersion service method, as returned by Glue.
member.exception: Access to a resource was denied.
Two processes are trying to modify a resource simultaneously.
A specified entity does not exist
An internal service error occurred.

A resource numerical limit was exceeded.

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.AmazonGlueClient.SearchTables(Amazon.Glue.Model.SearchTablesRequest)
member.summary:
Searches a set of tables based on properties in the table metadata as well as on the parent database. You can search against text or filter conditions.
You can only get tables that you have access to based on the security policies defined in Lake Formation. You need at least a read-only access to the table for it to be returned. If you do not have access to all the columns in the table, these columns will not be searched against when returning the list of tables back to you. If you have access to the columns but not the data in the columns, those columns and the associated metadata for those columns will be included in the search.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the SearchTables service method.
member.returns: The response from the SearchTables service method, as returned by Glue.
member.exception: An internal service error occurred.

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.AmazonGlueClient.StartExportLabelsTaskRun(Amazon.Glue.Model.StartExportLabelsTaskRunRequest)
member.summary: Begins an asynchronous task to export all labeled data for a particular transform. This task is the only label-related API call that is not part of the typical active learning workflow. You typically use StartExportLabelsTaskRun when you want to work with all of your existing labels at the same time, such as when you want to remove or change labels that were previously submitted as truth. This API operation accepts the TransformId whose labels you want to export and an Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) path to export the labels to. The operation returns a TaskRunId. You can check on the status of your task run by calling the GetMLTaskRun API.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the StartExportLabelsTaskRun service method.
member.returns: The response from the StartExportLabelsTaskRun service method, as returned by Glue.
member.exception: A specified entity does not exist
An internal service error occurred.
The input provided was not valid.
The operation timed out.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for StartExportLabelsTaskRun Operation

member.summary: Begins an asynchronous task to export all labeled data for a particular transform. This task is the only label-related API call that is not part of the typical active learning workflow. You typically use StartExportLabelsTaskRun when you want to work with all of your existing labels at the same time, such as when you want to remove or change labels that were previously submitted as truth. This API operation accepts the TransformId whose labels you want to export and an Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) path to export the labels to. The operation returns a TaskRunId. You can check on the status of your task run by calling the GetMLTaskRun API.

A cancellation token that can be used by other objects or threads to receive notice of cancellation.

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.AmazonGlueClient.StartImportLabelsTaskRun(Amazon.Glue.Model.StartImportLabelsTaskRunRequest)
member.summary:
Enables you to provide additional labels (examples of truth) to be used to teach the machine learning transform and improve its quality. This API operation is generally used as part of the active learning workflow that starts with the StartMLLabelingSetGenerationTaskRun call and that ultimately results in improving the quality of your machine learning transform.
After the StartMLLabelingSetGenerationTaskRun finishes, Glue machine learning will have generated a series of questions for humans to answer. (Answering these questions is often called 'labeling' in the machine learning workflows). In the case of the FindMatches transform, these questions are of the form, “What is the correct way to group these rows together into groups composed entirely of matching records?” After the labeling process is finished, users upload their answers/labels with a call to StartImportLabelsTaskRun. After StartImportLabelsTaskRun finishes, all future runs of the machine learning transform use the new and improved labels and perform a higher-quality transformation.
By default, StartMLLabelingSetGenerationTaskRun continually learns from and combines all labels that you upload unless you set Replace to true. If you set Replace to true, StartImportLabelsTaskRun deletes and forgets all previously uploaded labels and learns only from the exact set that you upload. Replacing labels can be helpful if you realize that you previously uploaded incorrect labels, and you believe that they are having a negative effect on your transform quality.
You can check on the status of your task run by calling the GetMLTaskRun operation.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the StartImportLabelsTaskRun service method.
member.returns: The response from the StartImportLabelsTaskRun service method, as returned by Glue.
member.exception: A specified entity does not exist
An internal service error occurred.
The input provided was not valid.
The operation timed out.
A resource numerical limit was exceeded.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for StartImportLabelsTaskRun Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.AmazonGlueClient.StartMLEvaluationTaskRun(Amazon.Glue.Model.StartMLEvaluationTaskRunRequest)
member.summary:
Starts a task to estimate the quality of the transform.
When you provide label sets as examples of truth, Glue machine learning uses some of those examples to learn from them. The rest of the labels are used as a test to estimate quality.
Returns a unique identifier for the run. You can call GetMLTaskRun to get more information about the stats of the EvaluationTaskRun.

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.AmazonGlueClient.StartMLLabelingSetGenerationTaskRun(Amazon.Glue.Model.StartMLLabelingSetGenerationTaskRunRequest)
member.summary:
Starts the active learning workflow for your machine learning transform to improve the transform's quality by generating label sets and adding labels.
When the StartMLLabelingSetGenerationTaskRun finishes, Glue will have generated a "labeling set" or a set of questions for humans to answer.
In the case of the FindMatches transform, these questions are of the form, “What is the correct way to group these rows together into groups composed entirely of matching records?”
After the labeling process is finished, you can upload your labels with a call to StartImportLabelsTaskRun. After StartImportLabelsTaskRun finishes, all future runs of the machine learning transform will use the new and improved labels and perform a higher-quality transformation.

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.AmazonGlueClient.UpdateSchema(Amazon.Glue.Model.UpdateSchemaRequest)
member.summary:
Updates the description, compatibility setting, or version checkpoint for a schema set.
For updating the compatibility setting, the call will not validate compatibility for the entire set of schema versions with the new compatibility setting. If the value for Compatibility is provided, the VersionNumber (a checkpoint) is also required. The API will validate the checkpoint version number for consistency.
If the value for the VersionNumber (checkpoint) is provided, Compatibility is optional and this can be used to set/reset a checkpoint for the schema.
This update will happen only if the schema is in the AVAILABLE state.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the UpdateSchema service method.
member.returns: The response from the UpdateSchema service method, as returned by Glue.
member.exception: Access to a resource was denied.
Two processes are trying to modify a resource simultaneously.
A specified entity does not exist
An internal service error occurred.
The input provided was not valid.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for UpdateSchema Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.IAmazonGlue.BatchDeleteTable(Amazon.Glue.Model.BatchDeleteTableRequest)
member.summary:
Deletes multiple tables at once.
After completing this operation, you no longer have access to the table versions and partitions that belong to the deleted table. Glue deletes these "orphaned" resources asynchronously in a timely manner, at the discretion of the service.
To ensure the immediate deletion of all related resources, before calling BatchDeleteTable, use DeleteTableVersion or BatchDeleteTableVersion, and DeletePartition or BatchDeletePartition, to delete any resources that belong to the table.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the BatchDeleteTable service method.
member.returns: The response from the BatchDeleteTable service method, as returned by Glue.
member.exception: A specified entity does not exist
An internal service error occurred.

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.IAmazonGlue.CreateMLTransform(Amazon.Glue.Model.CreateMLTransformRequest)
member.summary:
Creates an Glue machine learning transform. This operation creates the transform and all the necessary parameters to train it.
Call this operation as the first step in the process of using a machine learning transform (such as the FindMatches transform) for deduplicating data. You can provide an optional Description, in addition to the parameters that you want to use for your algorithm.
You must also specify certain parameters for the tasks that Glue runs on your behalf as part of learning from your data and creating a high-quality machine learning transform. These parameters include Role, and optionally, AllocatedCapacity, Timeout, and MaxRetries. For more information, see Jobs.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the CreateMLTransform service method.
member.returns: The response from the CreateMLTransform service method, as returned by Glue.
member.exception: Access to a resource was denied.
A resource to be created or added already exists.
The same unique identifier was associated with two different records.
An internal service error occurred.
The input provided was not valid.
The operation timed out.

member.seealso: REST API Reference for CreateMLTransform Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.IAmazonGlue.CreateSchema(Amazon.Glue.Model.CreateSchemaRequest)
member.summary:
Creates a new schema set and registers the schema definition. Returns an error if the schema set already exists without actually registering the version.
When the schema set is created, a version checkpoint will be set to the first version. Compatibility mode "DISABLED" restricts any additional schema versions from being added after the first schema version. For all other compatibility modes, validation of compatibility settings will be applied only from the second version onwards when the RegisterSchemaVersion API is used.
When this API is called without a RegistryId, this will create an entry for a "default-registry" in the registry database tables, if it is not already present.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the CreateSchema service method.
member.returns: The response from the CreateSchema service method, as returned by Glue.
member.exception: Access to a resource was denied.
A resource to be created or added already exists.
A specified entity does not exist
An internal service error occurred.
The input provided was not valid.
A resource numerical limit was exceeded.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for CreateSchema Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.IAmazonGlue.DeleteDatabase(Amazon.Glue.Model.DeleteDatabaseRequest)
member.summary:
Removes a specified database from a Data Catalog.
After completing this operation, you no longer have access to the tables (and all table versions and partitions that might belong to the tables) and the user-defined functions in the deleted database. Glue deletes these "orphaned" resources asynchronously in a timely manner, at the discretion of the service.
To ensure the immediate deletion of all related resources, before calling DeleteDatabase, use DeleteTableVersion or BatchDeleteTableVersion, DeletePartition or BatchDeletePartition, DeleteUserDefinedFunction, and DeleteTable or BatchDeleteTable, to delete any resources that belong to the database.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the DeleteDatabase service method.
member.returns: The response from the DeleteDatabase service method, as returned by Glue.

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.IAmazonGlue.DeleteMLTransform(Amazon.Glue.Model.DeleteMLTransformRequest)
member.summary: Deletes an Glue machine learning transform. Machine learning transforms are a special type of transform that use machine learning to learn the details of the transformation to be performed by learning from examples provided by humans. These transformations are then saved by Glue. If you no longer need a transform, you can delete it by calling DeleteMLTransforms. However, any Glue jobs that still reference the deleted transform will no longer succeed.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the DeleteMLTransform service method.
member.returns: The response from the DeleteMLTransform service method, as returned by Glue.

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.IAmazonGlue.DeleteSchemaVersions(Amazon.Glue.Model.DeleteSchemaVersionsRequest)
member.summary:
Remove versions from the specified schema. A version number or range may be supplied. If the compatibility mode forbids deleting of a version that is necessary, such as BACKWARDS_FULL, an error is returned. Calling the GetSchemaVersions API after this call will list the status of the deleted versions.
When the range of version numbers contain check pointed version, the API will return a 409 conflict and will not proceed with the deletion. You have to remove the checkpoint first using the DeleteSchemaCheckpoint API before using this API.
You cannot use the DeleteSchemaVersions API to delete the first schema version in the schema set. The first schema version can only be deleted by the DeleteSchema API. This operation will also delete the attached SchemaVersionMetadata under the schema versions. Hard deletes will be enforced on the database.
If the compatibility mode forbids deleting of a version that is necessary, such as BACKWARDS_FULL, an error is returned.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the DeleteSchemaVersions service method.
member.returns: The response from the DeleteSchemaVersions service method, as returned by Glue.
member.exception: Access to a resource was denied.
Two processes are trying to modify a resource simultaneously.
A specified entity does not exist
The input provided was not valid.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for DeleteSchemaVersions Operation

If the compatibility mode forbids deleting of a version that is necessary, such as BACKWARDS_FULL, an error is returned. When the range of version numbers contain check pointed version, the API will return a 409 conflict and will not proceed with the deletion. You have to remove the checkpoint first using the DeleteSchemaCheckpoint API before using this API.
You cannot use the DeleteSchemaVersions API to delete the first schema version in the schema set. The first schema version can only be deleted by the DeleteSchema API. This operation will also delete the attached SchemaVersionMetadata under the schema versions. Hard deletes will be enforced on the database.
If the compatibility mode forbids deleting of a version that is necessary, such as BACKWARDS_FULL, an error is returned.

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.IAmazonGlue.DeleteTableAsync(Amazon.Glue.Model.DeleteTableRequest,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary:
Removes a table definition from the Data Catalog.
After completing this operation, you no longer have access to the table versions and partitions that belong to the deleted table. Glue deletes these "orphaned" resources asynchronously in a timely manner, at the discretion of the service.
To ensure the immediate deletion of all related resources, before calling DeleteTable, use DeleteTableVersion or BatchDeleteTableVersion, and DeletePartition or BatchDeletePartition, to delete any resources that belong to the table.

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.IAmazonGlue.GetMLTaskRuns(Amazon.Glue.Model.GetMLTaskRunsRequest)
member.summary:
Gets a list of runs for a machine learning transform. Machine learning task runs are asynchronous tasks that Glue runs on your behalf as part of various machine learning workflows. You can get a sortable, filterable list of machine learning task runs by calling GetMLTaskRuns with their parent transform's TransformID and other optional parameters as documented in this section.
This operation returns a list of historic runs and must be paginated.

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.IAmazonGlue.GetSchemaByDefinition(Amazon.Glue.Model.GetSchemaByDefinitionRequest)
member.summary: Retrieves a schema by the SchemaDefinition. The schema definition is sent to the Schema Registry, canonicalized, and hashed. If the hash is matched within the scope of the SchemaName or ARN (or the default registry, if none is supplied), that schema’s metadata is returned. Otherwise, a 404 or NotFound error is returned. Schema versions in Deleted statuses will not be included in the results.

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.IAmazonGlue.ListCrawlers(Amazon.Glue.Model.ListCrawlersRequest)
member.summary:
Retrieves the names of all crawler resources in this Amazon Web Services account, or the resources with the specified tag. This operation allows you to see which resources are available in your account, and their names.
This operation takes the optional Tags field, which you can use as a filter on the response so that tagged resources can be retrieved as a group. If you choose to use tags filtering, only resources with the tag are retrieved.

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.IAmazonGlue.RegisterSchemaVersion(Amazon.Glue.Model.RegisterSchemaVersionRequest)
member.summary:
Adds a new version to the existing schema. Returns an error if new version of schema does not meet the compatibility requirements of the schema set. This API will not create a new schema set and will return a 404 error if the schema set is not already present in the Schema Registry.
If this is the first schema definition to be registered in the Schema Registry, this API will store the schema version and return immediately. Otherwise, this call has the potential to run longer than other operations due to compatibility modes. You can call the GetSchemaVersion API with the SchemaVersionId to check compatibility modes.
If the same schema definition is already stored in Schema Registry as a version, the schema ID of the existing schema is returned to the caller.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the RegisterSchemaVersion service method.
member.returns: The response from the RegisterSchemaVersion service method, as returned by Glue.
member.exception: Access to a resource was denied.

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.IAmazonGlue.SearchTables(Amazon.Glue.Model.SearchTablesRequest)
member.summary:
Searches a set of tables based on properties in the table metadata as well as on the parent database. You can search against text or filter conditions.
You can only get tables that you have access to based on the security policies defined in Lake Formation. You need at least a read-only access to the table for it to be returned. If you do not have access to all the columns in the table, these columns will not be searched against when returning the list of tables back to you. If you have access to the columns but not the data in the columns, those columns and the associated metadata for those columns will be included in the search.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the SearchTables service method.
member.returns: The response from the SearchTables service method, as returned by Glue.
member.exception: An internal service error occurred.

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.IAmazonGlue.StartExportLabelsTaskRun(Amazon.Glue.Model.StartExportLabelsTaskRunRequest)
member.summary: Begins an asynchronous task to export all labeled data for a particular transform. This task is the only label-related API call that is not part of the typical active learning workflow. You typically use StartExportLabelsTaskRun when you want to work with all of your existing labels at the same time, such as when you want to remove or change labels that were previously submitted as truth. This API operation accepts the TransformId whose labels you want to export and an Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) path to export the labels to. The operation returns a TaskRunId. You can check on the status of your task run by calling the GetMLTaskRun API.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the StartExportLabelsTaskRun service method.
member.returns: The response from the StartExportLabelsTaskRun service method, as returned by Glue.

The operation timed out.

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.IAmazonGlue.StartImportLabelsTaskRun(Amazon.Glue.Model.StartImportLabelsTaskRunRequest)
member.summary:
Enables you to provide additional labels (examples of truth) to be used to teach the machine learning transform and improve its quality. This API operation is generally used as part of the active learning workflow that starts with the StartMLLabelingSetGenerationTaskRun call and that ultimately results in improving the quality of your machine learning transform.
After the StartMLLabelingSetGenerationTaskRun finishes, Glue machine learning will have generated a series of questions for humans to answer. (Answering these questions is often called 'labeling' in the machine learning workflows). In the case of the FindMatches transform, these questions are of the form, “What is the correct way to group these rows together into groups composed entirely of matching records?” After the labeling process is finished, users upload their answers/labels with a call to StartImportLabelsTaskRun. After StartImportLabelsTaskRun finishes, all future runs of the machine learning transform use the new and improved labels and perform a higher-quality transformation.
By default, StartMLLabelingSetGenerationTaskRun continually learns from and combines all labels that you upload unless you set Replace to true. If you set Replace to true, StartImportLabelsTaskRun deletes and forgets all previously uploaded labels and learns only from the exact set that you upload. Replacing labels can be helpful if you realize that you previously uploaded incorrect labels, and you believe that they are having a negative effect on your transform quality.
You can check on the status of your task run by calling the GetMLTaskRun operation.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the StartImportLabelsTaskRun service method.
member.returns: The response from the StartImportLabelsTaskRun service method, as returned by Glue.
member.exception: A specified entity does not exist
An internal service error occurred.
The input provided was not valid.
The operation timed out.
A resource numerical limit was exceeded.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for StartImportLabelsTaskRun Operation

After StartImportLabelsTaskRun finishes, all future runs of the machine learning transform use the new and improved labels and perform a higher-quality transformation.
By default, StartMLLabelingSetGenerationTaskRun continually learns from and combines all labels that you upload unless you set Replace to true. member.summary:
Starts a task to estimate the quality of the transform.
When you provide label sets as examples of truth, Glue machine learning uses some of those examples to learn from them. The rest of the labels are used as a test to estimate quality.
Returns a unique identifier for the run. You can call GetMLTaskRun to get more information about the stats of the EvaluationTaskRun.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the StartMLEvaluationTaskRun service method.
member.returns: The response from the StartMLEvaluationTaskRun service method, as returned by Glue.
member.exception: Too many jobs are being run concurrently.
A specified entity does not exist
An internal service error occurred.
The input provided was not valid.
The machine learning transform is not ready to run.
The operation timed out.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for StartMLEvaluationTaskRun Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.IAmazonGlue.StartMLLabelingSetGenerationTaskRun(Amazon.Glue.Model.StartMLLabelingSetGenerationTaskRunRequest)
member.summary:
Starts the active learning workflow for your machine learning transform to improve the transform's quality by generating label sets and adding labels.
When the StartMLLabelingSetGenerationTaskRun finishes, Glue will have generated a "labeling set" or a set of questions for humans to answer.
In the case of the FindMatches transform, these questions are of the form, “What is the correct way to group these rows together into groups composed entirely of matching records?”
After the labeling process is finished, you can upload your labels with a call to StartImportLabelsTaskRun. After StartImportLabelsTaskRun finishes, all future runs of the machine learning transform will use the new and improved labels and perform a higher-quality transformation.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the StartMLLabelingSetGenerationTaskRun service method.
member.returns: The response from the StartMLLabelingSetGenerationTaskRun service method, as returned by Glue.
member.exception: Too many jobs are being run concurrently.
A specified entity does not exist
An internal service error occurred.
The input provided was not valid.
The operation timed out.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for StartMLLabelingSetGenerationTaskRun Operation

When the StartMLLabelingSetGenerationTaskRun finishes, Glue will have generated a "labeling set" or a set of questions for humans to answer.
In the case of the FindMatches transform, these questions are of the form, “What is the correct way to group these rows together into groups composed entirely of matching records?”
After the labeling process is finished, you can upload your labels with a call to StartImportLabelsTaskRun. After StartImportLabelsTaskRun finishes, all future runs of the machine learning transform will use the new and improved labels and perform a higher-quality transformation.

member.name: M:Amazon.Glue.IAmazonGlue.UpdateSchema(Amazon.Glue.Model.UpdateSchemaRequest)
member.summary:
Updates the description, compatibility setting, or version checkpoint for a schema set.
For updating the compatibility setting, the call will not validate compatibility for the entire set of schema versions with the new compatibility setting. If the value for Compatibility is provided, the VersionNumber (a checkpoint) is also required. The API will validate the checkpoint version number for consistency.
If the value for the VersionNumber (checkpoint) is provided, Compatibility is optional and this can be used to set/reset a checkpoint for the schema.
This update will happen only if the schema is in the AVAILABLE state.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the UpdateSchema service method.
member.returns: The response from the UpdateSchema service method, as returned by Glue.
member.exception: Access to a resource was denied.
Two processes are trying to modify a resource simultaneously.
A specified entity does not exist
An internal service error occurred.
The input provided was not valid.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for UpdateSchema Operation

For updating the compatibility setting, the call will not validate compatibility for the entire set of schema versions with the new compatibility setting. If the value for the VersionNumber (checkpoint) is provided, Compatibility is optional and this can be used to set/reset a checkpoint for the schema.
